content.description: A pervasive pattern of social and interpersonal deficits marked by acute discomfort with, and reduced capacity for, close relationships, along with cognitive or perceptual distortions and eccentric behaviors, beginning in early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A pattern of social/interpersonal deficits with cognitive/perceptual distortions and eccentric behavior, beginning by early adulthood, indicated by 5 or more: (1) ideas of reference, (2) odd beliefs or magical thinking, (3) unusual perceptual experiences, (4) odd thinking and speech, (5) suspiciousness or paranoid ideation, (6) inappropriate/constricted affect, (7) odd or eccentric behavior/appearance, (8) lack of close friends/confidants, (9) excessive social anxiety that does not diminish with familiarity. Does not occur exclusively during schizophrenia, bipolar disorder with psychotic features, or depressive disorder with psychotic features.
content.prevalence: Estimated around 3% of the general population; more common in first-degree relatives of individuals with schizophrenia.
content.age_of_onset: Early adulthood; traits may be observed in adolescence.
content.prognosis: Often chronic; some individuals may progress to schizophrenia or another psychotic disorder. Functioning can improve with treatment, but social and occupational impairment is common.

circuitry: Alterations in frontotemporal and limbic networks affecting social cognition and perception.
neurochemistry: Possible dopaminergic and glutamatergic dysregulation similar to, but less severe than, schizophrenia.
structural_findings: Mild reductions in temporal lobe and hippocampal volumes.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: Genetic overlap with schizophrenia spectrum disorders; environmental risk factors include early trauma and chronic social stress.

history_psychosocial: Detailed social history focusing on interpersonal functioning and developmental patterns.
History of unusual beliefs, perceptual experiences, and thinking style.
medical_assessment: Rule out neurological or substance-induced causes of perceptual disturbances.
standardized_measures: Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5 Personality Disorders (SCID-5-PD).

severity_levels.mild: Odd beliefs and behavior noticeable but manageable; some social relationships maintained.
severity_levels.moderate: More prominent perceptual distortions, greater social isolation, occupational impairment.
severity_levels.severe: Severe social dysfunction, persistent paranoid ideation, and marked eccentricity.

biological: First-degree relative with schizophrenia spectrum disorder
environmental: History of social rejection or isolation

impact_on_life.school_work: Difficulty functioning in group settings, poor job performance due to interpersonal challenges.
impact_on_life.medical: May delay or avoid medical care due to suspicion.

psychotherapy: Supportive therapy to build trust and social skills.
CBT targeting cognitive distortions and social anxiety.
medications: Low-dose antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone, olanzapine) for cognitive-perceptual symptoms.
SSRIs or other antidepressants if comorbid depression/anxiety present.
lifestyle_interventions: Structured social activities in safe environments.
Skills training to improve occupational functioning.
care_coordination: Collaboration with primary care for holistic management.

treatment_goals: Enhance social skills and comfort in interpersonal situations.
Improve functioning in work and daily life.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Misattributing odd beliefs to cultural norms without assessment.
Confusing symptoms with social anxiety disorder or introversion.
overdiagnosis_factors: Overinterpreting eccentric fashion or hobbies as pathological.
Mislabeling autism spectrum traits as schizotypal without developmental history.
warning_signs: Emergence of unusual beliefs or perceptual disturbances.
self_help_strategies: Engaging in structured social skills programs.

adolescents: May present with odd interests, magical thinking, and poor peer relationships.
older_adults: Symptoms may become less overt but social isolation often persists.

real_life_examples: A 25-year-old avoids coworkers, dresses in unusual layered clothing regardless of weather, and believes that casual remarks on TV contain special messages for them.
content.when_to_seek_help: If odd beliefs or social anxiety significantly impair daily life or cause distress.
